sub_title: Master student with entrepreneurial mindset | co-founder of BrewRight | MSc Forest and Nature Conservation | focus on management and conservation
summary:
I am fluent in sustainability and interested in its translation to business. I use knowledge to create bridges between disciplines and as a result create innovative solutions. Currently, I am in my second year of Forest and Nature Conservation at Wageningen University and Research. Next to my master, I am doing the entrepreneurs track and am a co-founder of the start up BrewRight. 

I have a bachelor in Watermanagement bachelor of science, majoring in Aquatic Eco Technology at the HZ University of Applied Sciences. I have always been involved in many extracurricular activities, such as chairwoman of DASA (student association), student representative and joined the Honours Program by making a documentary in sustainable fashion in 3 metropolitan cities. For my bachelor thesis I created a sustainable bioplastics to replace current plastic used for embellishments. 

I have an international mindset and am a well rounded person. I lived abroad in Australia, the UK and did my minor in Canada at the University of Waterloo. Overall, I am interested in topics such as conservation, sustainable fashion, sustainable agriculture, spatial planning and ecological engineering, circularity and the bio-based economy.

education.field_of_study: English A HL, Biology HL, Dutch B HL, Chemistry SL, History SL, Math SL, Art SL
education.grade: 33 points and a 7 on art as my seventh subject

certifications.name: Final Cut Pro X Guru: Titles and Effects
Final Cut Pro X 10.4.8 Essential Training

profile_positions.description: Improving conservation of species in zoos by integrating and combining different strategies, such as machine learning, phenotypic and genetic data. My focal species is the Egyptian tortoise (Testudo kleinmanni) by looking at both the zoo population (EAZA zoos) and private collection. Giving insight into the origin of individuals by utilising mitochondrial DNA and creating a haplotype network. Haploytpe knowledge is important for breeding strategies between EAZA zoos. Additionally, I created a standardised method to take pictures of shield morphology (phenotipic). This method is now integrated in the species guidelines (EAZA). These pictures are the data set used in a machine learning program to determine wild from bred tortoises. In the future this program be continuously trained in order to give more useful insights into problems related to conservation of the species. This strategy has the potential to be applicable to a wide range of species.
profile_positions.title: Master Thesis Student

profile_positions.description:
I conducted my thesis with the research group Marine Biobased Specialties. The main focus of this project was to answer "What is the importance of aquaculture in the fashion industry to combat climate change". The fashion industry is the second biggest polluter after the oil industry as well as plays a huge contribution to the issue with micro plastics in aquatic water bodies. My motivation was to find ways in aquaculture to solve some of the biggest issues. 

This journey started with an extensive desktop research into the fibers, pigments and binding material that can replace some of the polluting and backwards methods used in the fashion and textile industry. 
Based on the theoretical part afterwards I made the switch to application and practical side. This started with brainstorming of multiple solutions, validating the opportunities on feasibility, drafting plans of action, developing a leading concept to test in the lab, development of a prototype, testing the prototype on a few basic material parameters and finally started to do market research.

This is the first pilot Honours thesis, meaning that it was a continuation of my Honours Program topic: sustainable fashion which is linked and integrated in my studie field of Watermanagment. Therefore, rather than doing my thesis for half a year ended up taking more than a year go through multiple steps in research and product development. This represents more closely an entrepreneurial journey.
profile_positions.title: Bachelor Thesis Student

profile_positions.description:
Following this three month course next to my studies (part time) to learn about setting up a business. At the time I was working on creating a sustainable fashion company. The commitment level was one day in the week to discuss the homework (products and deliverables) that help shape and define all aspects of a company.

Lessons learned:
- validate every step in the solution - problem fit with your market (every step in the production chain)
- find partners in the company that have complementary skills and that you work well with 
- find a commitment level that works for everyone in an equal balance
- every experience you learn and those lessons you take with you to the next venture
- the first company you start will most likely not be a success
- find learning institutions to help shape the development of your business (research and development)
profile_positions.title: Start Up Course

profile_positions.description:
In my third year of my Bachelor I decided to do my minor at the University of Waterloo. I wanted to travel abroad and enrich my experiences with the Canadian lifestyle. At the same time I wanted to see what university would have to offer in terms of intellectual expansion of knowledge to build on my current knowledge. This led to new insights into the interaction between different ecosystems and oppurtunities to combine knowledge.

I followed 5 subjects from three different departments Biology, Geology and Environmental Studies. The sources selected were not available at our university but are further interests of mine that I wanted to pursue. I took two second year courses: Introduction to Sustainable Agriculture, which i scored 89% as my final grade. Also, Fundamentals of Microbiology, which I got 65% on. Additionally, two third year courses ReWilding and Ecological Restoration, which I scored 81% on and The Cryosphere with a final score of 90%. Lastly, I took a fourth year course called Biosphere Reserves as Social-Ecological Systems with a final score of 89%.
profile_positions.title: Student

profile_positions.description:
Working as a full time intern by Own Greens, which is focussed on hydroponic vertical farming as a form of sustainable agriculture. I wanted to discover and evaluate the potential of vertical farming as a solution for feeding a world when the climate is changing.

My main focus of the internship was research based, setting up and managing experiments for the production of a baseline data set with regard to water use, nutrients, and light. Gained more insight into the sector by attending conferences that the company had links to, or attended by managing a booth on the conference. Learned a lot about the sustainable agriculture sector and the processes involved, and I was able to apply what I have learned in my study in current relevant projects.
profile_positions.title: Intern

profile_positions.description:
DASA is an acronym for Delta Academy Study Association. The purpose of DASA is to serve the interest of the students of the Delta Academy, to stimulate interests, increase connectivity between students in order to minimise the distance between the theory of the study. 
As chairwomen my tasks include managing the board in order to effectively offer different opportunities such as, facilitating internship opportunities, participation of students at conferences, networking, invite guest lectures to host sessions or masterclasses.
profile_positions.title: Chairwoman

profile_positions.description: Opened up the official opening of the Young AIWW with a speech in fort of an audience of 150 young professionals. The talk focused on the student perspective, what students have to offer in the water sector.
profile_positions.title: Speaker at Young AIWW Opening

profile_positions.description: Second time with the WIL program the focus of this trip was the water sector of Portugal and the challenges faced. Gained more knowledge and experience as think about the water sector with a global perspective in mind. Focussed on refining skills such as, networking with the other delegates, gaining insight through field experience and guests speakers, sharing our passion through collaboration, creating more awareness, scenario planning, presenting skills and participating in world cafe, joining the Porto Innovation week as a delegate (PWIW).
profile_positions.title: WIL Porto

profile_positions.description: Delegate of the  Water Innovation Labs, which is a program to develops future water leaders to think holistically, design innovatively, and communicate effectively across cultures. By uniting young researchers, innovators, inventors, and entrepreneurs, WIL creates a platform to build new relationships, accelerate knowledge sharing, build transferable leadership skills, and co-develop potential solutions to water challenges across the globe. It is inter-generational and cross-sectoral learning for an ‘on the ground’ level of collaboration between young leaders, mentors and facilitators. Connecting directly with visionary resource experts in water treatment technologies, policy development, and community level water management who will share their global knowledge in the water sector.
profile_positions.title: WIL Netherlands

volunteer_experiences.description: I joined the volunteering program for the World Water Week in Stockholm. Together with more then 50 other people of all ages we functioned as the support team that helped out during sessions, welcomed delegates and in our free time joined different sessions and events. This was a great opportunity to broadening my understanding by gaining insights into the latest technologies, grow as an individual, but most importantly to network in order to cross-pollinate ideas.

This is an institute for the elderly, which was right next to my old high school. I was present every week ( once or twice a week) to help with the church ceremony, helped patients get to and from their room to the physiotherapy appointments and hosted the reading section by providing coffee, thee and conversation. Overall, I learned a lot about our current health system and enjoyed the time i spend although some cases were more confronting then others.
